div.p: First, the say de Prior and Consuls, according to the certaintie and trueth of the proofes and alligations made before them, by the parties, shall pronounce their Sentences cleerely, deciding the Proces, vpon paine to be punished by the Court of Parliament of the said place, vpon the reformation of their Sentences: As is contained in the second Article of the said Ordinances, in the Rubricke of Sentences.

div.head: ARTIC. 2.
div.p:
Item, after the said Prior and Consuls, haue pronounced their Sentence
without correcting, adding or diminishing the same, the said Register shall giue a Coppie of the sayde Sentences, to either of the sayd Parties, being required thereunto, vpon an arbritable penaltie to bee layd vpon him, and to be held a false man if hee doe the contrary; as is conteyned in the third Article of the foresaid Rubricke.

div.head: ARTIC. 3.
div.p: Item, the Kings pleasure is that all Sentences giuen by the saide Prior and Consuls, both interlocutory and definitiue, shall be of force and effect, euen as those of other Iudges, As is conteyned in the last Article of the sayde Rubricke of Sentences.

div.head: ARTICLE. 1.
div.p:
Item, the Merchants of the iurisdictions of the sayd Bourse of Thoulouze, as well by their owne consents,
as by the Commandement of the said Prior and Consuls, may commit their differences to Arbitrators, from whose sentence, they may appeale to the sayd Prior and Consuls, who as they shall see cause, may reforme, or confirme the Sentence of the said Arbitrators.

div.head: ARTIC. 2.
div.p: Item, the appellation of the Sentence of the Arbitrators, shall not be receiued by the sayde Prior and Consulls, before the Arbitrament bee performed, by the party that doth appeale: vpon condition to bee restored in the ende of Proces, if it bee so thought good by the saide Prior and Consulls. As is contained in the Kings Ordinances in the Rubricke of Arbitrators.

div.head: ARTIC. 3.
div.p:
Item, the sayd Prior, & Consuls, are to note, that no Merchant, nor other being of their Iurisdiction, can tranport, or make ouer their interest to any person Priuiledged, and not subiect to the same Iurisdiction, be it by gift, sale,
or Exchange, or by any other meanes, to the end to auoyd their Authoritie, vpon paine that the same transports or possessings, shal be of no effect, and the losse of their right and cause: As is contained in the first and second Articles of the Kings Ordinances, in the Rubricke of Sessions.

div.head: ARTIC. 4.
div.p: Item, all Notaries, who shall receiue any such transports or Sessions, shall be punished by the sayde Prior and Consuls, in an arbitrable penaltie: And further shall bee condemned, to pay vnto the aduerse Partie, all his costes and charges, which hee hath susteined by meanes thereof; As is contained in the first Article of foresaid Rubricke, taken of the common disposition of right.

div.head: Of Accusations.
div.p:
The Parties may accuse the said Prior and Consuls, and others of their Iurisdictions, if they haue lawfull cause so to
doe. And that not in writing but by word, in his presents whom they suspect: And their accusations shall bee summarily examined and decided; And if in case the sayd Prior and Consuls should bee accused, then the most auncient Merchants, and those who haue had the first preheminence in the said Bourse, shall sit in the place of the said Prior and Consuls: As is obserued in the other Iurisdictions; And contained in the Kings Ordinances, in the Rubricke of Accusations.

div.head: ARTICLE. 1.
div.p:
THe said Prior and Consuls, may distribute the Proces vnto the most auncient Merchants, that bee most expert in the matters that bee in question, to make a true report vnto the sayd Prior and Consuls: according to the allegations and proofes of the saide parties, to the ende to decide the same, according to right; without any
sallery to bee giuen to said Merchants, in regard of their report.

div.head: ARTIC. 2.
div.p: Item, all Merchants to whom the said Prior and Consuls shall distribute the Proces, they shall be subiect to take the aduice of the Aduocate, & Atturney of the said Bourse, or of any others, if there bee any difficultie in the cause, to the end to discerne the right, and to make the better report therof vnto the sayd Prior and Consuls, that they may the sooner end the same, according to reason and right, and at the charges of their Parties pursuants, like as the Conseruator of the Fayres of the sayd Citie of Lyon doth.

div.head: ARTIC. 1.
div.p:
FIrst all Charges and Damages, shall be taxed by the said Prior and Consulls to a certaine summe, as it shall truly appeare vnto them, by the discourse of the Proces, hauing a regard to the
qualitie of the Parties, and quantitie of the causes, without receiuing from the Parties any declaration of their charges, and without any other order of proceeding, as is contained in the last Article of the Kings Ordinances, in the Rubricke of Charges: like as the Conseruator of the Fayres of the sayd Lyon doth; And is contained in the Letters Patents of the month of February, hereafter specified.

div.head: ARTIC. 2.
div.p: Item, if for the repayre of the Charges, Damages, and Interest, any person were condemned in a penaltie, and to remaine in prison vntill he had satisfied the same, by the sayde Prior and Consuls, the sayd partie cannot bee by them inlarged, without the expresse consent of the Partie interessed, or that he haue satisfied him, As is contained in the seuenth and eight Articles in the Rubricke of Charges, And in the sixt Article of the Rubricke of Penalties.

div.head: Of Penalties.
div.p: ALl Penalties adiudged by the sayd Prior and Consuls (to be applyed as before said) shall be leauied without delay, as is contained in the second Article of the forefaid Rubricke of Penalties.

div.head: Exhortation.
div.p:
THe said Prior and Consuls, for the executing of the Kings pleasure, entertaining of their Iurisdiction, following the Order of the Conseruator of the Fayres of Lyon, auoyding of all bribing meanes, which the ministers of other Iurisdictions doe vse, and the easing of all Merchāts: To the end that they may more freely exercise ye course of their buying & selling of Merchandize, & causes of Exchange in all truth, They must haue regard, that they make no long proceedings, but by all meanes possible force out the trueth, speedily
to decide the cause in question, so farre as appertaineth to their knowledge, by the true affirmations of the Merchants, and not by fained, subtill, and craftie writings, which often times do darken the trueth, vnder the colour of fayre phrases declared in them; For so is the Kings pleasure, in the sayd Letters Patents of the Month of May, when as He commandeth them to proceed to Iudgements, in matters appertaining to their knowledge summarily, without figure of long pleas, and great solemnities of Proces.
